member.name: P:SpiceSharp.Simulations.BaseConfiguration.NoOperatingPointIterations
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the simulation should go straight to gmin stepping.

member.name: P:SpiceSharp.Simulations.BaseConfiguration.Gmin
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum conductance.
member.remarks: Convergence is mainly an issue with semiconductor junctions, which often lead to exponential curves. Exponential dependencies are very harsh on convergence. A lower Gmin will cause iterations to converge faster, but to a (slightly) wrong value. By steadily relaxing this value back to 0 it is possible to progressively reach a solution without having non-convergence.

member.name: P:SpiceSharp.Simulations.BaseConfiguration.GminSteps
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of steps to use when using gmin stepping to improve convergence.

member.name: P:SpiceSharp.Simulations.BaseConfiguration.SourceSteps
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of steps when using source stepping to improve convergence.
member.remarks: In source stepping, all sources are considered to be at 0 which has typically only one single solution (all nodes and currents are 0V and 0A). By increasing the source factor in small steps, it is possible to progressively reach a solution without having non-convergence.

member.param: The method that converts the base value type to a scalar.

member.name: M:SpiceSharp.Simulations.ModifiedNodalAnalysisHelper.ApplyDiagonalGmin(SpiceSharp.Algebra.SparseLinearSystem{System.Double},System.Double)
member.summary: Apply an additional conductance to the diagonal elements of a matrix that is typically constructed using Modified Nodal Analysis (MNA).

member.name: M:SpiceSharp.Simulations.ModifiedNodalAnalysisHelper.CountTwins``1(SpiceSharp.Algebra.Solver{``0},System.Int32,SpiceSharp.Algebra.MatrixElement{``0}@,SpiceSharp.Algebra.MatrixElement{``0}@,System.Func{``0,System.Double})
member.summary: Count the number of twins in a matrix that is typically constructed using Modified Nodal Analysis (MNA).
member.remarks: A twin is a matrix element that is equal to one, and also has a one on the transposed position. MNA formulation often leads to many twins, allowing us to save some time by searching for them beforehand.
member.param: The method that converts the base value type to a scalar.
member.returns: The number of twins found.

member.name: M:SpiceSharp.Simulations.NoiseState.Integrate(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: This subroutine evaluate the integration of the function NOISE = a * (FREQUENCY) ^ (EXPONENT) given two points from the curve. If EXPONENT is relatively close to 0, the noise is simply multiplied by the change in frequency. If it isn't, a more complicated expression must be used. Note that EXPONENT = -1 gives a different equation than EXPONENT != -1.
member.returns: The integrated noise.

member.summary: Creates a state for which a derivative with respect to time can be determined.
member.param: if set to false, the state is considered purely informative.
member.returns: A object that is compatible with this integration method.

For example, derived states can be used for finding a good time step by approximating the local truncation error (ie. the error made by taking discrete time steps). If you do not want the derivative to participate in these features, set to false.

member.summary: Calculate contribution to the jacobian matrix (or Y-matrix).
member.param: Derivative of the state variable with respect to the unknown variable.

member.summary: Calculate contribution to the rhs vector (right-hand side vector).
member.returns: A value that can be added to the element in the right-hand side vector.
member.remarks: The state variable is assumed to be linearly dependent of the unknown variables it is derived of. Ie. Q = dqdv * v (v is the unknown).

member.name: M:SpiceSharp.IntegrationMethods.SpiceIntegrationMethod.CreateDerivative(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a state for which a derivative with respect to time can be determined.
member.param: if set to false, the state is considered purely informative.
member.returns: A object that is compatible with this integration method.
member.remarks: Tracked derivatives are used in more advanced features implemented by the integration method. For example, derived states can be used for finding a good time step by approximating the local truncation error (ie. the error made by taking discrete time steps). If you do not want the derivative to participate in these features, set to false.
